quoteFirst: than we know ourselves to be, in our cooler moments, say, for instance, when mounted and at the covert-side, a fine country before us, every probability of a run, a north-east wind rather keener than agreeable, bathing our uncovered face like cold water, and a chill misgiving that last week’s frost is not thoroughly out of the ground, particularly just under the fences, and that the thaw which rejoiced us so exceedingly after dinner, has only succeeded in making the surface greasy, and not in rendering it soft. Ah! if we could always feel as we do for that glorious hour from about
quoteLast: , when we stretch our napkin-covered legs towards the cheerful fire, blazing and crackling, and sparkling into rubies, as it reflects itself in our brimming glass of Bordeaux, what good fellows we should all be! how generous, how open-hearted, and how successful in our avocations and pursuits! The process of digestion, that highly important function, when properly performed, seems to endow us with all the most admirable qualities of manhood.
title: Market Harborough, and Inside the Bar
author: Whyte-Melville, G. J. (George John), 1821-1878; Charlton, John, 1849-1917 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: 4 Taube 7:30 A. M. and 11:30 A. M.; bombardment
title: The Bombardment of Reims
author: Ferree, Barr, 1862-1924

quoteFirst: Under the conditions visualized in Figure 3, the field of observation at midnight is only one-fourth as large as the field of observation earlier in the evening. Thus the twenty-four birds seen from
quoteLast: , represent not twice as many birds actually flying per unit of space as the twelve observed from 11:30 to 12:30 A. M., but only half the amount.
title: A Quantitative Study of the Nocturnal Migration of Birds
author: Lowery, George H., Jr., 1913-1978

quoteFirst: Moreover, before a call which is intended to initiate an acquaintance can be made, notice of the caller's intention, and of the day proposed, must first be sent. These formal calls are made from
quoteTime: seven to eight in the evening
quoteLast: , and it is not considered polite to leave before the hour has expired. During this period iced water is handed round in elegant glasses, furnished with silver trays and tortoiseshell covers.
title:
A Visit to Java
With an Account of the Founding of Singapore
author: Worsfold, W. Basil (William Basil), 1858-1939

quoteTime: seven to eight in the evening

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: the jury in the trial of Ambrose Doane for treason-felony returned a verdict of not guilty without leaving their seats.  This was a foregone conclusion.
title: The Fur Bringers: A Story of the Canadian Northwest
author: Footner, Hulbert, 1879-1944

quoteFirst: By a super-human effort he got his boat clear, and sculled down hard all, reaching the boat-house at
quoteLast: .  He had just presence of mind enough to shout the message for Chalker to the boat- boy, with a promise of twopence if he delivered it at once; and then with a desperate rush he just succeeded in reaching the chapel and squeezing himself in at the door as the bell ceased ringing.
title: The Willoughby Captains
author: Reed, Talbot Baines, 1852-1893

quoteFirst: P.M., one killed; three Woodcocks killed from
quoteLast: ; two Snipe killed at 9.20 P.M.; continuous flocks of Redwings from 7 to 10 P.M., nine killed; eighty-two Skylarks killed from 9 to 11.30 P.M.; and seven Song Thrushes killed at 11 P.M. (E.N.E., 3; C. M. O.) This movement was continued in the early hours of the 14th. (_q. v.

quoteFirst: From
quoteTime: seven to eight in the evening
quoteLast: the men drop in, and a vague murmur begins; the murmur grows louder and more confused as time passes, and by ten o'clock our company are in full cry, and all the pipes are in full blast. When I stole quietly in, I thought the scene was hideous enough in its dull way.
title:

quoteFirst: _, we did not get up) till eight o’clock Chapel, and attended Cathedral service, which commenced with the Litany at half-past ten; we went into school from four to five to do Greek Testament, and to Chapel again at five. In Cloister-time, Sixth book, and Senior part went into school from
quoteLast: , which period was called “Grotius time,” after the author whose work, “De Veritate,” was then substituted for Greek Testament.
title: School-life at Winchester College
author: Mansfield, Robert Blachford, 1824-1908
